page.title: 09Riding of the Marches
page.content: At Rosebank riding school, preparation begins at 4am for the riding of the marches. The riding itself begins at 7.45am on a June day each year. On the 50th anniversary in 1982, about 400 riders took part. Normally it's between 100 and 200. The marches have not changed since 1932, when Major J.Lyndsay Drummond was{Cornet}. {Cornet's Lasses} were introduced in 1939. To be a Cornet or Lass, you must be born in Dumfries. The marches are done to keep Dumfries a{Royal Burgh}until next year's festivities. In the ceremony a charter is handed to the {Provost}, requesting Dumfries to be kept a Burgh. The Cornet and { {Lynors} mark the town Boundary by 'stobbing and nogging', meaning sticking in a post and flag. 1986 is the 800th anniversary of the Burgh.
